text: , also romanized as Nihombashi, is a business district of Chūō in Tokyo, Japan. The district grew up around the bridge of the same name.Chuo City Tourist Association, "Nihonbashi" . Retrieved 2012-3-25. The bridge connects two sides of the Nihonbashi River. A series of bridges at the same site have had the same name since the 17th century. Traditionally, all distances in Japan are measured from the centerpoint of the Nihonbashi Bridge. This custom began in the Edo period.Richie, Donald. (1994). Introducing Tokyo, p. 15. ==History== In the Edo period, the Nihonbashi Bridge was the start of Tōkaidō road which connected Edo and Kyoto.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Tōkaidō" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 973. The earliest Nihonbashi Bridge was made of wood. It was completed in 1603. The current bridge is made of stone. It was completed in 1911. In 2009, Nihonbashi was recognized as one of the 100 Landscapes of Japan which best show contemporary Japan and its culture in the Heisei period."100 Landscapes of Heisei announced," Yomiuri Shimbun. May 2009.
